title: 112_s187
content: The "Biofuels Market Expansion Act of 2011" requires manufacturers to ensure a certain percentage of dual-fueled automobiles and light duty trucks are produced for sale in the United States. The "Biofuels Market Expansion Act of 2011" mandates that manufacturers produce a specific percentage of dual-fueled vehicles. Model years 2014 and 2015 require 50 percent, while model year 2016 and onwards need 90 percent. There is an exception for vehicles running solely on electricity. Additionally, regulations must be established within a year of the Act's enactment, and a new section is added to the table of sections for chapter 329 of title 49, United States Code. The Blender Pump Grant Program defines terms like "blender pump," "E-85 fuel," "ethanol fuel blend," and "major fuel distributor." A blender pump can dispense various gasoline and ethanol blends, including E-85 fuel with 85% ethanol content. Major fuel distributors are those who own or market refinery output. The Secretary will provide grants to eligible facilities for installing blender pump fuel infrastructure and providing subgrants to direct retailers of ethanol fuel blends for the direct retail sale of ethanol fuel blends, including E-85 fuel. The Secretary will provide grants for installing blender pump fuel infrastructure and subgrants to retailers of ethanol fuel blends, with a federal share of up to 50%. Retailers must offer ethanol blends for sale for at least 2 years within a 4-year period or repay the grant. Authorization of appropriations includes $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. The Clean Air Act authorizes appropriations for the installation of blender pumps by major fuel distributors at owned and branded stations. This includes specific funding amounts for fiscal years 2012 to 2016. The amendment defines E-85 fuel and ethanol fuel blend for clarity. The Clean Air Act authorizes appropriations for the installation of blender pumps by major fuel distributors at owned and branded stations. The term 'major fuel distributor' is defined as any person that owns a refinery or directly markets the output of a refinery. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with the EPA Administrator and the Secretary of Agriculture, shall promulgate regulations to ensure compliance with gasoline sales. The Clean Air Act authorizes major fuel distributors to install blender pumps at owned and branded stations, dispensing E-85 fuel and ethanol blends for at least 5 years. The applicable percentage of stations is determined according to a specified table. The Clean Air Act mandates major fuel distributors to install blender pumps at majority-owned and branded stations, dispensing E-85 fuel and ethanol blends at specified percentages for each calendar year. The Secretary mandates major fuel distributors to install blender pumps at their stations, ensuring financial responsibility for installation costs and proper functioning. Major fuel distributors can earn production credits for exceeding blender pump installation requirements, allowing them to apply credits to consecutive calendar years or trade them. Major fuel distributors can sell credits to other distributors to help them meet requirements, but cannot use purchased credits to fulfill geographic distribution requirements. Loan guarantees are provided for projects constructing renewable fuel pipelines. Loan guarantees are provided for projects constructing renewable fuel pipelines, with the definition of renewable fuel and renewable fuel pipelines clarified and the guarantee amount set at 80 percent of the project cost. Loan guarantees are available for the rapid deployment of renewable fuel pipelines, with the guarantee amount set at 80 percent of the project cost. The Secretary of Energy must create necessary regulations within 90 days of this Act's enactment to implement the amendments.
